John Arrowwood wrote:

>Which gives me an idea...I imagine a mechanism that helps the network 
>remember where it came from, so it is more likely to go back to it as a 
>fall-back:
>
>Have the connection weight be a series of numbers, a minimum of 3.  The 
>actual weight is the sum of all of them.  The first number is the one that 
>  
>
I like the idea John. I was thinking of something similar whereby 
connection weights get stiffer or more rigid with age. So new 
connections would be mutated over the full range of possible values, but 
older connections that have stood the test of time would not be 
perturbed at all. I'm sure this isn't a new idea but it's certainly 
worth trying it out with NEAT. I am thinking of implementing a simple 
version of the connection rigidity idea by just setting a 'fixed' bit 
following a pruning phase. The idea being that any structure that 
survived pruning has proved itself to be useful and should not be 
perturbed any more.

If multiple weight values are used as you suggest, then I see that as 
laying down strata, the earlier layers of which are older and more rigid 
than the younger layers. I have an old paper here that discusses this 
concept (or something very similar if my memory serves) in the context 
of networks that can fall-back to functionality that was learned earlier 
in life by ignoring the younger strata. In some ways it could be 
equivalent to mood in biological brains - people are better or worse at 
certain tasks depending on mood - mood could partly the effect of 
chemicals that switch neurons into a state where they use only the older 
connections and not the newer ones, or perhaps biological axons actually 
have strata of some kind.

Colin.
